content.raw:
Sorry for the wrong copy&paste... Of course I used `-DUSE_PCH=ON`. I saw the lines about precompiled headers being compiled, and all these gch files in my build directory.

Why do you think the change wouldn't work for Debug? Have you tested that? Because all the Debug flags (like `-g -O0`) are passed in `CMAKE_C_FLAGS` (at least at my system).
content.html:
Sorry for the wrong copy&paste... Of course I used -DUSE_PCH=ON. I saw the lines about precompiled headers being compiled, and all these gch files in my build directory.

Why do you think the change wouldn't work for Debug? Have you tested that? Because all the Debug flags (like -g -O0) are passed in CMAKE_C_FLAGS (at least at my system).

content.raw:
Seems you've hardcoded some flags related to your specific build type.

I changed these lines in `GazeboUtils.cmake` and now it works for me:


```
#!cmake
set(FLAGS -fPIC -x c++-header)

separate_arguments(ARGS UNIX_COMMAND "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} ${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} ${ARGN}")
```
content.html:
Seems you've hardcoded some flags related to your specific build type.

I changed these lines in GazeboUtils.cmake and now it works for me:

set(FLAGS -fPIC -x c++-header)

separate_arguments(ARGS UNIX_COMMAND "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} ${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} ${ARGN}")

content.raw:
I build using catkin with this command:

`catkin build -vic --no-deps -j3 --cmake-args  -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON   -DUSE_DOUBLE_PRECISION=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DUSE_PCH=OFF -- gazebo`

And yes, I'm on branch gazebo8.
content.html:
I build using catkin with this command:

catkin build -vic --no-deps -j3 --cmake-args -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -DUSE_DOUBLE_PRECISION=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DUSE_PCH=OFF -- gazebo

And yes, I'm on branch gazebo8.

pull_request.title: Add basic support for gnu precompiled headers

update.description:
# Implementation
Each subfolder of gazebo get's it's own header. That header is then included at the top of every file using gcc's ```-include``` option.

The naming convention is ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` which is transformed to ```$subfolder_pch.hh.out.gch```, and ```$subfodler_pch.hh.out``` is used with ```-include``` on all the files. The reason for the .out is to prevent the source files from finding the original ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` in the same directory before it found the pch in the build directory.

 - Currently using cmake macro called use_pch, but it may need some work.
 - Included some headers to be precompiled, but they are not optimized. Many expensive things are missing like Qt, OGRE.
 - The macro doesn't extend well for things like Qt which need lots of extra flags
 - Not extended to all subfolders yet (sensors, util, msgs, ... )

#Timing information
 - According to @_jrivero_,  "we can demonstrate that this code change improves the compilation time in at least 125 seconds in speedy (probably SDD) machines. In not so fast I/O machines (like kitt) this improvement is even better (~250s), around the 7%."

# How to test
```cmake .. -DUSE_PCH=ON```



Also there's a bit of trailing whitespace removed because vim does that for me.
update.title: Add basic support for gnu precompiled headers

pull_request.title: Add basic support for gnu precompiled headers

update.description:
# Implementation
Each subfolder of gazebo get's it's own header. That header is then included at the top of every file using gcc's ```-include``` option.

The naming convention is ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` which is transformed to ```$subfolder_pch.hh.out.gch```, and ```$subfodler_pch.hh.out``` is used with ```-include``` on all the files. The reason for the .out is to prevent the source files from finding the original ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` in the same directory before it found the pch in the build directory.

 - Currently using cmake macro called use_pch, but it may need some work.
 - Included some headers to be precompiled, but they are not optimized. Many expensive things are missing like Qt, OGRE.
 - The macro doesn't extend well for things like Qt which need lots of extra flags
 - Not extended to all subfolders yet (sensors, util, msgs, ... )

#Timing information
 - According to @_jrivero_,  "we can demonstrate that this code change improves the compilation time in at least 125 seconds in speedy (probably SDD) machines. In not so fast I/O machines (like kitt) this improvement is even better (~250s), around the 7%."

# How to test
```cmake .. -DUSE_PCH=ON```



Also there's a bit of trailing whitespace removed because vim does that for me.
update.title: Add basic support for gnu precompiled headers

content.raw: These are not what I would call curated, they are actually just every include that would compile that was outside of our control (not gazeno, sdf, ode, or ignition). I found that adding more never hurts, so long as there is no risk that we will change them often. I will add the command I used to generate the initial list, and the copyright info.
content.html: These are not what I would call curated, they are actually just every include that would compile that was outside of our control (not gazeno, sdf, ode, or ignition). I found that adding more never hurts, so long as there is no risk that we will change them often. I will add the command I used to generate the initial list, and the copyright info.

pullrequest.title: Add basic support for gnu precompiled headers

content.raw:
I think these double `ifs` can be reduce to:


```
#!c++

if (USE_PCH)
    set(MORE_FLAGS "-pthread")
    add_pch(gazebo_common common_pch.hh ${MORE_FLAGS})
endif()
```

We can expand this if statement when (or if) we enable PCH on OSX and Windows.
content.html:
I think these double ifs can be reduce to:

if (USE_PCH)
    set(MORE_FLAGS "-pthread")
    add_pch(gazebo_common common_pch.hh ${MORE_FLAGS})
endif()

We can expand this if statement when (or if) we enable PCH on OSX and Windows.
